awd_titl_txt: Theoretical and Experimental Study of Functional Association of Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching theme of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of functional oligomerization of proteins and its relation to protein aggregation. When proteins acquire a destabilizing mutation that thermodynamically or kinetically impairs their folding they often aggregate in cytoplasm which leads to deleterious consequences for an organism. Functional oligomerization is a newly discovered mechanism by which destabilized proteins avoid aggregation by forming specific highly active and soluble dimers or in rare cases higher order oligomers. This mechanism plays a key role in providing high fitness escape route in response to potentially deleterious destabilizing mutations or dangerous variations of the environment. This project will provide a fully atomistically resolved insight into plasticity of protein structure and function in response to mutations and changing environments. This study focuses on an essential enzyme, Dihydrofolate Reductase, (DHFR) whose destabilized mutants were found to form soluble functional dimers in E. Coli at elevated temperature. The PI will develop advanced computational tools to predict possible structures and thermodynamic stabilities of oligomers formed by mutant forms of DHFR and formulate hypotheses of domain swap mechanisms, which will be tested by mutagenesis experiments. The mutations, which switch between functional oligomerization and non-functional aggregation will be identified and their effect on protein stability and cellular fitness will be experimentally tested. Finally, the structures of soluble oligomers will be determined using NMR technique to provide a feedback for evaluation and improvement of simulation techniques and force-fields. 

The computational and experimental tools developed in this work will allow researchers to study adaptation through oligomerization in other systems of Biological interest. Since this project encompasses a broad range of approaches and techniques, from computational studies to experimental research in vitro and in vivo,  postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students will receive broad training.  The evolutionary implications of this research are significant and will be communicated to general public through a series of public lectures on molecular foundations of evolution, raising the scientific literacy and appreciation of the excitement of scientific research at the frontiers of human knowledge. More generally this research will have direct impact on environmental and agricultural studies by advancing our mechanistic molecular level understanding of how proteomes of microorganisms adjust to changing environments. This project is being jointly supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems program in the Physics Division.

por.por_cntn:
In order to function proteins in living cells often form complexes such as homooligomers (complexes between identical proteins) and hetero oligomers (complexes in which different proteins participate).  The main goal of this project is to uncover the physical-chemical and evolutionary mechanisms that determine functional association of proteins. The most challenging aspect of this problem is that such associations occur in crowded cellular environment where potential for wrong associations (misinteractions) is high. Thus proteins must not only evolve strong functional interactions but also weaken many possible alternatives (misinteractions) including self-interaction leading to aggregation with discernible consequences for fitness and possible disease phenotype. Our lab established experimentally that functional association of proteins might proceed as a result of mutations that destabilize single monomers yet provide driving force for them to dimerize or oligomerize by forming intertwined (domain-swapped) protein oligomers where partial unfolding of each unit precedes the oligomerization event. We developed novel simulation tools such as multichain all-atom Monte-Carlo techniques and applied it to investigate thermodynamics and kinetics of concurrent partial unfolding and oligomerization. Application of the model to DHFR from E. coli bacterium (the enzyme which was determined experimentally to dimerize upon mutational destabilization) provided a detailed structural model of the dimer where C-terminal beta-hairpins serve as “anchors” for oligomerization. This finding also explains our experimental observation that overexpression of DHFR is toxic to the cell. In a careful set of experiments and multichain simulations we determined that such overexpression causes massive misinteractions with other proteins which in some cases prevent their normal functioning in living cells. Thus our study established physical principles, which govern the optimal level of expression of proteins in the cell. In a related development we applied our new simulation tools to study cataract-causing aggregation of D-gamma-crystallin, the key component of human eye lens. It has been well established that several mutations in this protein cause its aggregation at physiological conditions leading to cataract. Our joint experimental and computational study revealed that aggregation-causing mutations destabilize one domain of D-gamma crystallin causing its partial unfolding to expose cysteine residues which then form intramolecular non-native transient disulfide bonds leading to a precursor of the aggregated state. Our simulations pinpointed and experiments confirmed specific cysteine residues that are responsible for promoting aggregation providing therefore a detailed mechanistic understanding of a molecular process of great physiological and medical importance. Overall this interdisciplinary experimental and theoretical study on the interface of chemistry, physics and biology provided key insights into common molecular mechanisms that are responsible for significant fitness and physiological effects. Our research leads to deep understanding how evolution balances the effects of mutations on protein stability and protein-protein interactions to maintain physiological associations between proteins and avoid detrimental non-functional ones. Detailed mechanistic insights obtained in this work form a basis of a new paradigm in evolutionary biology: Evolutionary dynamics emerges as a multivariable process where different biophysical traits interact to constraint plausible paths leading to adaptation to new environments and evolution of new functions. Furthermore, in this project we developed new computational tools to predict energetics of protein-protein interactions and stability effects of mutations that are freely available to scientific community from our labs website.
